docs.lead_paragraph: The woman, in her 70's, answered my questions with a shrug of resignation, as if we were talking about the price of beef or the inevitable loss of youth, not her breast cancer. Her words and body language conveyed a clear message: it was no big deal. The tumors had sprouted on her left breast like mushrooms in a dank forest: different shapes, sizes and colors. As they were mostly on the underside of her breast, she claimed not to notice them. Like the doctor in Solzhenitsyn's ''Cancer Ward,'' I wanted to ask her: ''Why didn't you come earlier? Why come here when you are practically a corpse?''

headline.main: First Battle Of Cancer: Deep Denial

docs.abstract: Dr Sandeep Jauhar articleon denial that drives some women to delay seeking treatment for breast cancer (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The clock on the gymnasium wall was stuck at 10 minutes before 6. I discovered this when the hundreds of tired, angry women sprawled around me on the hard floor burst into applause as one of our fallen comrades was wheeled in on a gurney, covered eyebrows to toenails in what appeared to be a big sheet of tinfoil. She joined the other dehydrated souls huddled on Army cots, each wrapped like a giant baked potato in the thin aluminum blankets that keep you from descending into shock, and I realized that the clock hadn't budged since we arrived a half-hour before.

docs.lead_paragraph: From the moment it hit the streets of Boston in 1970, the groundbreaking women's health book ''Our Bodies, Ourselves'' -- then a newsprint edition with no cover that sold for 35 cents -- roused its readers to question medical authority and seize control of their own health care. With its frank discussion of intercourse, childbirth and lesbianism, detailed drawings of genitals and compelling first-person accounts, the book has been a medical bible for several generations of women, guiding them from menstruation and motherhood to menopause and mortality. A hallmark of feminism with four million English copies distributed worldwide, its language has been strident, its approach strictly secular and its belief in individual rights unyielding.

headline.main: 'Our Bodies' Is Recast for Latina Culture

docs.abstract: New Spanish-language edition of groundbreaking women's health book Our Bodies, Ourselves, intended for growing Hispanic population, stresses mutual help over self-help and woman's need to take care of herself so she can better care for others; coordinating editor Ester Shapiro Rok says stress on interdependence instead of individualism reflects importance of relationships in Latin culture; photos (M)

headline.main: Stroke Survivors Celebrate Success of Restraint Therapy

docs.abstract: Experimental rehabilitation called constraint-induced movement therapy is helping some stroke survivors regain use of disabled arms to varying degrees; therapy involves reprogramming of brain; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Preventive medicine often involves making a best guess based on less than complete scientific information. So it was with smoking, when people were advised to quit long before there was incontrovertible proof that it caused cancer. So it was also with cholesterol, when people were told to lower their blood levels long before research showed that doing so prevented heart attacks. And so it is now with homocysteine, an amino acid in blood that when elevated has been linked to heart attacks and strokes as well as a host of other health problems, from miscarriage to Alzheimer's disease.

headline.main: Taking Action Before the Verdict Is In

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on responding to research linking elevated blood levels of amino acid homocysteine to heart attacks and host of other ailments; photo (M)
